titleStmt.title: Sixteene propositions in Parliament. Touching the manner and forme for church governement, by bishops and the clergie of this kingdome. Whereunto is added. The opinion of the English doctors and divines at the synod at Dort, concerning episcopacy and lay-elders. Also the names of 14. divines more which are added to the synod by the House of Parliament. With an order by the Lords and Commons in Parliament, touching the governement of the church. Hen. Elsing. Cler. Parl. D. Com.

titleStmt.title: Sixteene propositions in Parliament. Touching the manner and forme for church governement, by bishops and the clergie of this kingdome. Whereunto is added. Synod of Dort (1618-1619)

notesStmt.note: "The opinion of the English doctors" (p. 4-5) is signed at end: Georgius Caleton (i.e. Carleton) Iohn Davenant, Gualter Balcanquall, Samutell Ward, Thomas Goad.
The order (p. 6) was separately issued as a broadside with caption: Die sabbati 9. April. 1642.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: SIXTEENE PROPOSITIONS in Parliament.
Touching the manner and forme for Church Governement, by Bi≈øhops and the Clergie of this Kingdome.
Whereunto is added. The opinion of the Engli≈øh Doctors and Divines at the Synod at Dort, Concerning Epi≈øcopacy and Lay-Elders.
Al≈øo the Names of 14. Divines more which are Added to the Synod by the Hou≈øe of PARLIAMENT.
With an Order by the Lords and Commons in Parliament, touching the Governement of the Church.
Hen. El≈øing. Cler. Parl. D. Com.
London, Printed for I. T. 1642.

div.head: THE ORDER For Church-Governement Read in the Hou≈øe of COMMONS. 1642.
div.p: Imprimis EVery ≈øeverall Shire of England and Wales, to be a ≈øeverall Circuite or Dioce≈ø≈øe, for the Eccle≈øia≈øticke Iuri≈ødiction, excepting Yorke≈øhire which is to be divided into three.
II. A Con≈øtant Presbyterie of Twelve choy≈øe Divines to be ≈øelected in every Shire or Dioce≈ø≈øe.
III. A Con≈øtant Pre≈øident to bee e≈øtabli≈øhed as a Bi≈øhop over this Presbyterie.

IV. This Bi≈øhop in each Dioce≈ø≈øe to ordaine, ≈øu≈øpend, deprive, degrade, excommunicate by: and with the con≈øent and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of ≈øeven Divines of his Presbyterie then pre≈øent and not otherwi≈øe.

V. The times of Ordination throughout the land to
be foure times every yeare, viz. the fir≈øt of May, the fir≈øt of Augu≈øt, the fir≈øt of November, and the fir≈øt of February.
VI. Every Bi≈øhop con≈øtantly to re≈øide within his Dioce≈ø≈øe, in ≈øome one prime, or chiefe City or Towne within his Dioce≈ø≈øe, as i ‚Ä¢ particular.

VII. Every Bi≈øhop to have one ≈øpeciall particular Congregation, to be cho≈øen out of the mo≈øt convenient for di≈øtance of place, from his chiefe re≈øidence, and the Riche≈øt in value that may bee had: where he ≈øhall duely preach unle≈ø≈øe he be lawfully hindred, and then ≈øhall take care that his Cure be well ≈øupplyed by another.
VIII. No Bi≈øhop ≈øhall remove or be tran≈ølated from the Bi≈øhopricke which he ≈øhall fir≈øt undertake.

IX. Upon every death, or other avoidance of a Bi≈øhop, the King to grant a Conge d'elire to the whole Clergie of that Dioce≈ø≈øe, and they to pre≈øent three of the Presbyters afore≈øaid, and the King to choo≈øe and nominate whom he plea≈øe of them.

X. The fir≈øt Presbyters of every ≈øhire to bee named by the Parliament, and afterwards upon the death or other avoidance of any Presbyter, the remaining Presbyters to choo≈øe another out of the Pari≈øh
Mini≈øters of that ≈øhire, and this to bee done within one month next after ≈øuch death or avoidance.

XI. No Bi≈øhop or Clergie-man to exerci≈øe or have any Temorall Office, or ≈øeculir employment, but onely, for the pre≈øent, to hold and keepe the probate of wills, untill the Parliament ≈øhall otherwi≈øe re≈øolve.

XII. The Bi≈øhop once a yeare (at Mid≈øummer) to ≈øummon a Dioce≈øan Synod, there to heare, and by generall vote, to determine all ≈øuch matter of ≈øcandall in Life and Doctrine among the Clergie-men, as ≈øhall be pre≈øented unto them.

XIII. Every three yeares, a Nationall Sinod to be, which for per≈øons ≈øhall con≈øi≈øt of all the Bi≈øhops in the Land, and of two Presbiters to be cho≈øen by the re≈øt out of each Presbitery, and of two Clarkes to be cho≈øen out of everie Dioce≈ø≈øe, by the Clergie thereof.
XIV. This Nationall Synod to make and ordaine Canons of the Government of the Church, but they not to bind untill they be confirmed by Parliament.

XV. Every Bi≈øhop to have over and above the Benefice afore≈øaid, a certaine con≈øtant Rent allowed
and allotted proportionall to the Dioce≈ø≈øe wherein he is to-Officiate, that is to ≈øay, every Presbyter to have a con≈øtant yearely profit above his Benefice.

XVI. As for the Revenue of the Bi≈øhops, Deanes, and Chapters, &c. a ≈øtrict Survey to be taken of all their rents and profits, and the ≈øame to be repre≈øented at the beginning of our next Convention, and in the meane time no Lea≈øe to be renewed, nor Timber to be felled.

div.head: The opinion of the Engli≈øh Doctors and Divines at the Synod of Dort, concerning Epi≈øcopacy and Lay-Elders.
div.p: WE thought not fit to content our ≈øelves with warrantable ≈øilence, but con≈øulting together what was fit to be done in delivering our opinions. We ioyntly conclude that how≈øever our Church Di≈øcipline had not been Synodically taxed, nor theirs avowed, yet it was coÃÑvenient for us, (who were a≈øsured in our con≈øienceÃÑs that their Presbyteriall Parity, and Laicall Presbytery was repugnant to the Di≈øcipline e≈øtabli≈øhed by the Apo≈øtles, and retained in our Church to declare our Iudgment.

We therefore pro≈øe≈ø≈øed and declared our vtter di≈ø≈øent in that point, and further ≈øhewed that by our Saviour a Parity of Mini≈øters was never Iu≈øtituted, That Chri≈øt ordained Twelve Apo≈øtles, and ≈øeventy Di≈øciples; That the Authority of tho≈øe twelve was
aboue the other; That the Church pre≈øerved this Order left by our Saviour. And therefore when the extraordinary Authority of the Apo≈øtles cea≈øed, yet their ordinary Authority continued in Bi≈øhops, who ≈øucceeded them who were by the Apo≈øtles them≈øelves left in the government of the Church to ordaine Mini≈øters, and to ≈øee that they who were ≈øo ordained ≈øhould preach no other Doctrin; That in an inferior degree the Mini≈øters who were governed by Bi≈øhops ≈øucceeded the 70. Di≈øciples, That this Order hath been maintained in the Church, from the time of the Apo≈øtls. And herein we appealed to the Iudgment of Antiquity, or of any learned man now living, if any could speak to the contrary: To this our exception and allegations, not one word was an≈øwered by any of the Synodiques either ≈øtrangers or Provincialls. Moreover, in our Private conver≈øing with the mo≈øt eminent of the Mini≈øtery there, we found divers times (upon ocea≈øion of our declaring unto them the Order and manner of our Church Government) that they were more ready to deplore then defend their own e≈øtate, and wi≈øhed rather, then hoped to be made like the flouri≈øhing Church of England.

closer.signed:
Ita Te≈øtamur.
Georgius Caleton.
Gualter Balcanquall
Iohn Davenant.
Samuell Ward.
Thomas Goad.

div.head: The Lords added 14. Divines to the Bill ≈øent to them about the A≈ø≈øembly of Divines which were there.

list.item: DOctor Hamond of Penthur≈øt in Kent.
Ma≈øter Lance of Saint Michaels Querne London.
Doctor Mar≈øh of Saint Dun≈øtones in Fleet≈øtreet.
Ma≈øter Carter of Denton in Buckingham≈øhire.
Ma≈øter Lifur, Vicar of Sh ‚Ä¢ rly.

div.head: An Order by the Lords and Commons in Parliament touching the Governement and Liturgie of the Church.
div.p: THe Lords and Commons doe declare, they intend a due and nece≈ø≈øary reformation of the Governement and Liturgie of the Church, and to take away nothing in the one or the other, but what ≈øhall be evill, and ju≈øtly offencive, or at lea≈øt unnece≈ø≈øary and burthen≈øome, and for the better effecting hereof, ≈øpeedily to have con≈øultation with godly and learned Divines, and becau≈øe this will never of it ≈øelfe attaine the end ≈øought therein, they will therefore u≈øe their utmo≈øt endeavours to e≈øtabli≈øh Learned and Preaching Mini≈øters, with a good and ≈øufficient maintenance throughout the whole Kingdome, wherin many darke corners are mi≈øerably de≈øtitute of the meanes of ≈øalvation, and many poore Mini≈øters want nece≈ø≈øary provi≈øion.

closer.signed: Hen. El≈øyng. Cler. par. D. C.
